message: where to go?
largely need to prototype a daemon that'll be listening on a port, and a bunch of daemons that will talk to that central one
you thinking raw sockets, or zmq or something?
You should checkout eventlet or gevent. Should get you pretty far without having to work too hard.
@alex i was thinking raw sockets, but may go the eventlet route. (may in the end write the daemon not-inpython, but we'll see that ltaer down the line)
the hope is to keep performance high and dependencies low though.
i'm just such a web programmer i've always had, you know, a web server to handle this kind of stuff for me.
eventlet is only sorta-kinda not raw sockets. Technically they get monkey patched but the API is the same
i wanted to try zeromq for a chat style project but it seems like you have to opt out of all the special happiness to get bidirectional sockets
luckily this should be pretty monodirectional
the receiver will have to say "bad form/i'm down," but not much other than that
yeah, zeromq has a request-response socket that's for that. i can't vouch for zeromq though since i didn't dig into it for anything.
full duplex request/response isn't super easy
@markpasc why not just use two sockets for that?
and keep the special happiness
@tilgovi while i wouldn't expect the app to have to scale a whole lot, it seems weirdly wasteful to have to use up an extra server port just because i want to use a weird socket library
yeah, if i did it manually with one socket there wouldn't be responses i don't think
cause i sure don't know how to do that either
i might just do that if i get back to that project
i really do wanna play around with zmq
Ditto on needing to play around with zeromq.  Depending on if it lives up to expectations, it could be super useful for Convore stuff.
@simonw Probably not, Wednesday is going to be...hectic...for the Convore team.
yeah, what are you up to?
launching
sad to also probably miss http://killdashninesf.eventbrite.com/
have you considered node.js ?
@ericflo are you going to the Zed Shaw Mongrel2 talk in SF on Wednesday?
best of luck with it :) you going completely open-to-all?
hehehe
related: https://github.com/JustinTulloss/zeromq.node
not Python, but trivially easy to write network servers in
whoa!
@simonw Yep! *shudders*
